Maybe you misunderstood my "racists" comment.  Please allow me to help you with this.  The Take a Knee movement was never anti-American, but was co-opted by some who have tried to make it un-American because they take anything and try twisting it into something against the left, and because they refuse to listen and understand the reasons behind it.  Everyone might not like it, but just as burning the flag is protected free speech, there's nothing illegal about taking a knee.  In fact, one could argue that both are the highest example of American freedom.  No one is taking anything from me when they burn a flag or take a knee during the National Anthem. Thank you for "honoring" my dad. However, to say that I am ridding on his coat tail is very disrespectful and an invalid statement. To be ridding on his coat tail would mean that I would be in the services myself expecting that same rank and benefits that he has and had. I am not in the services and no I do not ride his coat tail. You do not know me and I do not know you, so to tell me about the kind of relationship that I have with my dad seems to be assuming and that's one thing you should never do. Moving on, to say that "if it wasn't for the Europeans, you and I wouldn't be here" as if that is something that African Americans wanted from the jump is also an ignorant statement. I would have loved to at least experienced what my life would have been like before my ancestors were deprived of their livelihood and taken from their land. I realize that for most white Americans, living in America is a "privilege" but to African Americans like myself who are faced with injustices and racial differences on a daily basis, it is not a privilege to be here. I just see it as life as we know it. Also, because I am a woman of faith, I owe my entire existence to my Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ! He is the real reason I am here. Now, I shouldn't have to be the one doing all the educating here, so when you do research on the great work Colin Kaepernick has been doing out in the communities; before, during, and after his Pro football career, then you can come to me and have and educated discussion on why he is being looked at as a role model. I don't Idolize anyone but God, but I will acknowledge those who are setting the examples of being great human beings to all mankind. Why are you so upset that his talents earned him a spot to play in the NFL or that NIKE went to Colin and asked him to be the face of the Ad Campaign? Viconius Vortex I see your point. I would argue that athletes are the only ones in the arena expected to act a "certain" way during the national anthem. During the professional games that I have attended, there are a large number of people still talking, walking, etc during the anthem.  A lot of them are the same people that would argue that kneeling is a disrespect but ignore they're talking and other things. I'd also like to point out that athletes are millionaires because of the revenue their employer makes. We can't argue that the CEO, CFO, or whatever high position you'd name for Johnson and Johnson shouldn't have the right to speak out on certain things because we take our hard earned money and buy baby powder, Neutrogena, or Aveeno. Yet this is the stance many will take against athletes. I think the misrepresentation of the police has to do with the media and people not wanting to research the statistics of the issue. It's never been said that all cops are corrupt, racist, or employing brutal tactics on African Americans. But there is something to be said when mass school shooters like Dimitrios Pagourtzis or Nikolas Cruz are somehow peacefully taken into custody while many African Americans seem to be so threatening while sitting in their cars at traffic lights. The real question is what makes "Kaepernick and those" come off as over-privileged? Their money shouldn't equate to them being over-priviledged. They all worked for where they are same as most senior executives of prospering companies. Believe me, if they were just handing out NFL, NBA, MLB, and NHL contracts, there would be a lot of people in line receiving benefits that they hadn't necessarily earned. rodfromms¬† That certainly would be a helpful, i.e. the real face of the cause. But there are some fundamental issues with the cause, namely the misrepresentation about the police. Instead, promote the idea that there should be NO police brutality then you have a start. The primary problem is the venue. Every player's entire career from youth to professional has a clearly defined role they are expected to play on and off the field. Playing any sport in America has ALWAYS included patriotic respect as a core element, and for the non-Americans out there, this is fact and not opinion. Unlike the 60's, the Flag and service (military & first responders) to the country is no longer a "bad" thing. Playing of the national anthem at the start of the game is seen as a ritual acknowledgement of those that serve/d the American Ideal and reaffirm the promise to build a better USA. The promise to make a better USA is a guiding principal that the average American can/does expect from their fellow citizens. The pure existence of these athletes is only as a result of the freedom and opportunities afforded by others sacrifice. They are not expected to deride that ritual of humility and respect. They are millionaires being exulted by average citizens who expect such behavior from their "heroes", a contract on national civility. There is plenty of time other than during the national anthem to promote a cause. They have plenty of time and money to do it after/between games too, and MANY of them do. Most Americans see the kneeling behavior as disrespectful to the fans and degrading to the players themselves. It doesn't matter what the cause is they are promoting, at that moment they are standing on the shoulders of giants and Americans expect humility in light of that fact. I didn't mean this to be a soap box, but the topic gets so skewed by media and opinion bating. Kaepernick and those that kneel come off as over-privileged people even to Americans.

GLO GANG PABLO¬† I hear you. I don't agree with the taking of the knee, but feel he does have the right to do it. My problem is that his/movement has no tangible goals and the facts don't bear out when talking about the police. (There are bad cops just not as claimed.) Even that aside, the culture dictated the behavior at these games and it hasn't shifted like other recent cultural changes like gay marriage, multi sexuals etc. Because the core of the American Football fans still venerate the countries history and the sacrifices made to create and preserve it; disrespecting that core group won't make meaningful change. So, it's ill advised IMHO, and no amount of grandstanding or wearing pig/police socks at practice will gain any converts. In fact just the opposite.
For Nike, they've had a long storied past of sweatshop labor accusations occurring in Asia (from Asian nations too). Those have been quite of late having mostly been papered over with money and politicians. but this stirs it back up. But since outside the USA it's fashionable to pound on the big kid on the block, and Nike as a global corporation will benefit, at least in theory.
As for sacrifice. No, I don't think he has to be penniless and destitute. I think you're over compensating on his behalf. The fact is he simply isn't broke. This just makes him more of a millionaire and shows he and his movement can be bought at an individual level. This will enrage the core NFL fans too. He's asking a large group of people who spend hard earned money to abandon their principals and embrace his commitment to a cause in which they don't believe. It won't work, IMHO. Just like the rest of the world's sports fans, most are hard working people that spend their resources to enjoy life and don't need lectures by millionaires playing a game for entertainment. That angers up the blood.

TBH I didn‚Äôt support why he did what he did, and I wish they wouldn‚Äôt use it for publicity in fashion, it‚Äôs quite uncomfortable to see that a disrespectful act is set to be an acceptable thing in the sports industry. Not saying he‚Äôs the only person to do it in history, but things usually don‚Äôt end well for anyone when it‚Äôs blown into this movement that ends up causing much more harm than good. And I have seen it happen many times everywhere.

kat_minded the black lives matter movement is not what they tell people, it‚Äôs a violent and aggressive protest that promotes disorder and harming those who disagree, as well as tearing down those who don‚Äôt agree with them as well. After what happened in Dallas and how people who support the movement react when others say something different (ex: all lives matter) him supporting those actions and trying to promote supporting throughout the country is disrespectful to the country as it is causing disorder and violence. My view is that when a famous person wants to go and use his  or her status to spread a bad influence (though it doesn‚Äôt happen often luckily) they should not be promoted or supported.

4 U.S. Code ¬ß 8 - Respect for flag




U.S. Code¬†‚Ä∫¬†Title 4¬†‚Ä∫¬†Chapter 1¬†‚Ä∫ ¬ß 8

4 U.S. Code ¬ß 8 - Respect for flag

No disrespect should be shown to the flag of the United¬†States¬†of America; the flag should not be dipped to any¬†personor thing. Regimental colors, State flags, and organization or institutional flags are to be dipped as a mark of honor.

(a)

The flag should never be displayed with the union down, except as a signal of dire distress in instances of extreme danger to life or property.

(b)

The flag should never touch anything beneath it, such as the ground, the floor, water, or merchandise.

(c)

The flag should never be carried flat or horizontally, but always aloft and free.

(d)

The flag should never be used as wearing apparel, bedding, or drapery. It should never be festooned, drawn back, nor up, in folds, but always allowed to fall free. Bunting of blue, white, and red, always arranged with the blue above, the white in the middle, and the red below, should be used for covering a speaker‚Äôs desk, draping the front of the platform, and for decoration in general.

(e)

The flag should never be fastened, displayed, used, or stored in such a manner as to permit it to be easily torn, soiled, or damaged in any way.

(f)

The flag should never be used as a covering for a ceiling.

(g)

The flag should never have placed upon it, nor on any part of it, nor attached to it any mark, insignia, letter, word, figure, design, picture, or drawing of any nature.

(h)

The flag should never be used as a receptacle for receiving, holding, carrying, or delivering anything.

(i)

The flag should never be used for advertising purposes in any manner whatsoever. It should not be embroidered on such articles as cushions or handkerchiefs and the like, printed or otherwise impressed on paper napkins or boxes or anything that is designed for temporary use and discard. Advertising signs should not be fastened to a staff or halyard from which the flag is flown.

(j)

No part of the flag should ever be used as a costume or athletic uniform. However, a flag patch may be affixed to the uniform of military personnel, firemen, policemen, and members of patriotic organizations. The flag represents a living country and is itself considered a living thing. Therefore, the lapel flag pin being a replica, should be worn on the left lapel near the heart.

(k)

The flag, when it is in such condition that it is no longer a fitting emblem for display, should be destroyed in a dignified way, preferably by burning.

Everyone who refers to the military in a Colin Kaepernick discussion missed the point and blatantly decided to follow a narrative to ignore a cause worthy of protest.  No NFL player kneeled to protest the flag, the military, or the anthem.  The media and others characterized the protest that way as a distraction.  Even if someone wanted to protest the anthem, I wouldn't be against it.  There are 27 amendments to the U.S. Constitutions, but zero changes to the Star Spangled Banner which still mentions slavery.  A soldier told Kaep to kneel if he wanted to protest honorably.  As a veteran of 3 wars myself, I have zero issues with the protest.  As a soldier who has been a part of numerous military funerals, I have on many occasions gotten down on 1 knee and presented a folded flag to the loved one of a deceased soldier.  This fake fury is truly upsetting.  Only 1% of the population are currently in the military.  Stop speaking for them.

Colin's beliefs and my beliefs are different.  The manner in which he chooses to protest and the manner in which I would choose to protest would also be different.  When I comment to speak on his behalf it is mainly to discredit those who are trying to distract from his message of civil mistreatment in our country.  I know the specific reason why he is kneeling and am okay with it.  

If someone chose to kneel at a military funeral that is obviously a sign of disrespect because it isn't the time or place.  I know some would want to use that answer to prove a point but then that would show they don't understand the point of protest.  It would show people don't understand the unique power an athlete has to protest.  Protests need to be seen and heard to be effective.  When normal people protest they bring signs and chant slogans to be seen and heard.  People also register for permits so they can gather in a place where they know they can be seen.  A normal protest can be seen by hundreds or maybe thousands if they get some local news coverage.  A protest wouldn't get much positive attention at a funeral.  If it did get attention it wouldn't be positive or help a cause.  An NFL player kneeling is instantly witnessed by millions.  The only problem with kneeling as a form of protest is that it can't immediately transmit a message.  Others can derive a message that isn't coming from the protester.  The media has hijacked the message to lead people to believe the military, flag, and anthem are being protested.  Kneeling gained visibility needed for protest but failed at delivering the proper message.

I can speak for myself and I believe I am well spoken enough to protest in another form.  I wouldn't expect most athletes to be comfortable in more complicated forms of protest.  Colin is capable and people need to remember he hasn't taken a knee in over 2 years.  Media is keeping that narrative alive.

You are correct.  I did not protest while I was in the military, but I did not accept any unfair treatment for myself or soldiers while I was active.  I didn't just accept orders without thought, but I probably had more leeway since I was in intelligence.  Personally, I stand for the National Anthem.  If I need to protest, I have the means to do it in another way.  I just can't stand the people who are trying to change the narrative of someone's protest when they don't care about the issues being protested.
Colin is just one activist and he isn't the only one who is being treated unjustly while trying to protest.  If you have a problem with the Nike ad, that is just an opinion, but we still aren't talking about the police.  I just wrote 5 paragraphs without talking about the treatment we receive from the police which is the actual issue.  The media is winning.  We are constantly distracted from the actual issue.

jack johnson I'm in favour of making use of countries where employment opportunities are so scarce that an ethical sweatshop will make a significant positive change to the community (no children, no outrageous hours worked, protected staff, and a fair wage). 

They can change the cycle of poverty, especially for 3rd would countries where the dollar is very favourable, and the government has failed to transform the country. 

I am NOT in favour of the majority of sweatshops as they trap children into a permanent cycle of poverty, abuse, and human rights violations. 

My acceptance of the need for sweatshops is highly conditional. It HAS to benefit the individuals, the community and the corporation. It must apply western work standards to ensure ethical treatment of the people and the environment.
so what ur saying is ur in favor of sweatshop products?

kommisar While I agree that it is a completely different environment and economy to what the Westernized countries have, there are some areas that could be debated. 

On the extreme end of the sweatshop crimes are children as young as 5 years old, earning a few cents an hour, and working 100 hours a week. 

The extreme hours with low pay that children are often forced into (what child would volunteer for this?), also means that  these children never receive an education, and the family only ever subsists and never breaks the perpetual cycle of poverty. 

On the other side there are some more ethical sweatshops which pay far better wages and the families are able to develop themselves beyond just mere hand to mouth subsistence. 

There is evidence to support the necessary evil of ethical sweatshop in the industrialisation of a country. Indeed it wasn't that long ago that cheap labour helped transform many economies that we know today. 

I would argue that if a low but fair wage were paid ( for that economy), children under 14 were not used, and the workers were protected from rape and extreme 100 week hours, or punishing shifts of 72 hours in a single stretch, the suffering of a single generation could be radically transformed for the benefit of the coming generations. 

However, as many sweatshops have continued to exist with abysmal circumstance for the worker over generations, there is evidence that a harsh exploitation is beneficial only to the company/government. THESE are the ones that we should be aware of and stop supporting until they can add vakue to the community development. 

Nike/Jordan have cleaned up their act significantly but as recently as 2017 human rights violations were found in Honduras and Cambodia.

@Leevy where are you finding your statistics that black people are 3 times more likely to be shot by police? 
All official documentation & records (from local precincts to the FBI) all point to the exact opposite. 
For instance, in 2017, 457 white people were killed by police vs 223 for black people. (Hispanics accounted for 179)
So far in 2018, the numbers are very similar: 211 white people, 102 black people, and 68 Hispanics, have been killed by officers. 
Considering this, the fact that black people shoot officers in much, much higher ratios, becomes a lot more alarming because the cause & correlation you spoke of disappears. 
I am all for any person's right to peaceful protest & assembly and I wouldn't deter anyone from bringing attention to a cause that deeply matters to them, but when people, especially those that are high profile like Kapernick, lead people to believe things that aren't true, this helps no one & furthers the divide between officers & civilians and pits Americans against Americans. 
At the end of the day, who does this help? 
With all that being said, I ABSOLUTELY AGREE that there are WAY too many instances of officers shooting unarmed  civilians- of all colors & backgrounds. 
I believe Kapernick's demonstrations would have been a lot more effective, and garnered a lot more support, if HE hadn't made it about race. THAT is my point. 
I WANT us to come together & find a solution. I pray that it happens sooner rather than later. But until we stop making everything about race, sex, social status, ect. and start seeing everyone as HUMAN BEINGS, we will continue to see things decline. 

I Thank you for the civil discussion. I feel it has been enlightening & hope you do as well. God Bless.

Honest question, looking for an honest answer. I am open to the possibility that minorities suffer from police brutality at a higher rate than whites. But I am yet to find any conclusive statistics to back this up. Can anyone provide me with evidence of this? Im not just looking for number or percentage of whites vs. blacks that are killed by cops. To me thats not enough evidence. What I am looking for is the number or percentage of minorities that are UNJUSTLY killed by cops. In other words cases where the cops are #1 white #2 they killed a minority #3 (Most importantly) the cop was FOUND GUILTY in the court of law by UNJUSTLY killing a minority #4 the percentage of #3 between whites & minorities. If someone can provide me with those statistics from a reliable source that would be the concrete evidence I need. Thanks!

Richard Lewis,
You will never find those numbers.  In order for a LEO to be convicted of an unjustified homicide, the DA for the jurisdiction would first have to charge him (or her) with the crime and convict him in Court.  But in virtually all cases of a LEO using deadly force resulting in the death of a suspect, the incident would first have to be reviewed by the LEO's own Dept.  Not surprisingly, it's very, very seldom that a Review Board will find that a shooting by one of their own people was unjustified.  In which case, the DA would have virtually NO chance of getting a conviction in Court.

It's true that we civilians are protected by those men and women in Law Enforcement who are that 'thin blue line' between order and chaos.  It's also true that, in most cases, the 'blue wall' they form to protect their own - even when guilty - is almost impenetrable!

Flashback: Nike Blasted by Bernie Sanders in 1997 for Outsourcing Jobs to Sweatshops in Vietnam
252

4 Sep 2018212
In 1997, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) blasted the Nike multinational corporation for outsourcing much of their workforce to alleged sweatshops in Vietnam.
During a speech on the Senate floor against the job-killing North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) free trade deal that was being pushed at the time, Sanders called out Nike for its documented history of outsourcing jobs to the lowest wage regions of the world to maximize profits and cut labor costs. Sanders asked:

The real wages for American workers are continuing to decline. Yes, the CEOs of major corporations saw a 54 percent increase in their compensation. Yes, the stock market is hitting off the wall. Yes, the rich are getting richer. But what about the average worker. Well the front pages of corporate America‚Äôs newspapers don‚Äôt talk about it. But for the average American worker, despite all the so-called boom, the real wages are going down. People continue to work long hours for low wages‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶

If our workers are forced to compete against desperate people in Mexico or in China who are trying to get by on starvation wages. If we merge these economies, what is the ultimate result?

Sanders began reading from a 1997 Associated Press report about workers in Vietnam at a Nike factory who rioted after the multinational corporation allegedly failed to pay them the $2.50 minimum wage.

Sanders said:


If there‚Äôs an employer over here who is going to pay someone 50 cents an hour, why would they pay you $15 or $20 an hour. [Emphasis added]

Now, Nike has a habit of going to wherever in the world, wages are at rock bottom. Mexico is much too high wage for Nike. They‚Äôre now in Vietnam. They have determined that wages in Vietnam are the lowest in the world. [Emphasis added]


 
Let me quote this, ‚ÄòIn demonstrations on Friday, workers burned cars and ransacked the factory‚Äôs office, saying the company, Nike, wasn‚Äôt paying them a $2.50 a day minimum wage.‚Äô That‚Äôs our competition. That is what much of what the global economy is about. American workers, you really want to compete? You really want to go below $2.50 an hour? Nike might come back to America and hire you if you‚Äôre ready to go for $2 a day. You ready to do that? [Emphasis added]

"(Robert E. Lee) even supported getting rid of the Confederate flag after the Civil War ended. He didn't want it flying above Washington College, of which he was president after the war."

"Lee did not want such divisive symbols following him to the grave," Horn wrote. "At his funeral in 1870, flags were notably absent from the procession. Former Confederate soldiers marching did not don their old military uniforms, and neither did the body they buried."

"According to (Robert E. Lee's biographer, Jonathan) Horn, Lee's daughter wrote, "His Confederate uniform would have been 'treason' perhaps!"

"Lee believed countries that erased visible signs of civil war recovered from conflicts quicker," Horn told PBS. "He was worried that by keeping these symbols alive, it would keep the divisions alive."

I very much agreed with Trump WHEN he agreed with Nikki Haley about retiring the Confederate flag to museums. Unfortunately, he flipped on the issue in 2016 due to a large number of Reps who were upset about giving in to PC.  

You have to understand that the issue is so complicated that almost nobody seems to really understand the different feelings of the different groups who still want to display the Confederate flag ‚Äì or at least not eradicate it, aside from a large number who actually are either racist or prejudiced. 

Still, I feel strongly that it should be a very rare case in which the Confederate flag is displayed and only then if those who support that can explain to the rest of us why it is important, because I just don‚Äôt get it. 

Bottom line though, not everyone who cares about the Confederate flag is racist.

ERYNRENEE ‚Äì RE: YOU KNOW WHAT'S REALLY DISRESPECTFUL..‚Äù  

I am 100% with you on Trump's disrespect to a Gold Star family, ‚Äúinsulting our NATO allies, and behaving like a petulant brat and refusing to apologize for saying a POW isn't a war hero.... ‚Äú

However, I do not think it is fair to unduly criticize Trump for not ‚Äúrefusing to release a WH statement about his death and thanking him for his sacrifice, and raising the WH flag to full staff in defiance‚Äù WITHOUT at least acknowledging Sen McCain‚Äôs uncharacteristic pettiness at requesting Trump not attend his funeral.  That was a very clear, very public and very serious slap in the face.  

Obviously, Trump partially deserved it by inviting those ill-feelings with his petulant behavior.  Still, disinviting a sitting president from attending a funeral in which ill-feelings could have been buried and forgiveness given was very unstatesman-like.

Just FYI, while Trump did not give a proclamation to KEEP the flag at half-staff past the normal, traditional period, the flag was in fact lowered to half-staff again on the same day it was raised due to criticism.  

Trump should also have forgiven McCain and buried his ill-feelings by acting appropriately, even if McCain did not.  Trump will regret being so small in the future (we hope). Of course, McCain already regrets his lack of forgiveness (assuming he really did make the request and not his family) since it was contrary to the commandments of our father.

Where does the scotus say that you do not have the freedom to form any contract you wish and to give up any rights that you possess? 

IF the scotus ever said such a thing, then it said so directly and wholly in contradiction to the Constitution and directly in violation of our inalienable rights. 

While the GOVERNMENT cannot force you to participate in patriotic rituals, neither can it force you to NOT willingly give up any right that you have.  If it were so, then the fundamental underpinning of our Constitution would cease to exist.  

By our being citizens of the U.S., we consent to give up a certain measure of our inalienable rights in exchange for certain protections that we are not capable of providing for ourselves.  Obviously, since the rights belong to us, we can also consent to give up rights by contract ‚Äì like almost every single person who signs an employment contract does. But note, this is done voluntarily - like Kaepernick did.

BeastBen_2004,

You said, " And your point on his "Qualifications to be president" I did not miss, it was irrelevant seeing as though there is no proof that he did it for self service, it was just your opinion."

Again, I think you still missed the points.

1. I have had a "bone spur" on my heel, technically called "plantar fasciitis".  The pain is tremendous!  Pain like that you don't forget!  For that reason, I don't think he had any bone spurs. (opinion)

2. IF I had had bone spurs, and IF I had a doctor write me a letter excusing me from the Draft, especially in the mid-1960s, I would remember who he was because I would have been so grateful! (opinion)

3. In the mid-60s, during the Viet Nam War, Draft eligible men were NOT excused from the Draft because the man's personal physician wrote a "strongly worded" letter.  They had to be examined by a Selective Service physician. (fact)

I have a close relative who had a bad knee, the result of a football injury.  He had x-rays and his medical record that clearly showed that he wasn't a fit candidate for Military Service, but he still had to go for the pre-induction physical.  It was only after being examined by their physician did the Selective Service classify him 1Y, which was ironic, since he WANTED to enlist. (fact)

THAT's why DT's claim that a "strongly worded letter" got him excused doesn't pass the smell test. (opinion, based on fact)

4. His disdain for and outrageously insulting comments about John McCain and his Service and sacrifice to this Country are inexcusable!  I get it that they were said during a hotly contested campaign.  So what!  There is no excuse for those remarks.  Especially from a man who would be our CIC. (fact)

5. His disdain for and outrageously insulting remarks as they applied to all Viet Nam War POWs. (fact)

6. His disdain for and outrageously insulting and/or insensitive remarks about/to Gold Star Mothers. (facts)

These are not the only reasons why I have a low opinion of DT.  But they'll do, for me.  Don't misunderstand me!  If I were still Serving in uniform, I would salute and render to him all the respect due to the President of the United States and my Commander in Chief.  But I would still have very little respect for the man.  He's done and said enough to waste all of those chips as far as I'm concerned.

The man has literally talked to more doctors and people and businessmen etc. then most people have being a businessmen himself. It has also been 40 odd years since that happened and I highly doubt he has that well of a memory, the human brain is programmed to remember what is important in the moment not from the past as it is over and will not matter anymore ( Why do you think businessmen have secretary's ). And your point on his "Qualifications to be president" I did not miss, it was irrelevant seeing as though there is no proof that he did it for self service, it was just your opinion.

BeastBen_2004,

Some friends and I were talking not long ago, and the question was asked, "What is the first thing you'd do if you were elected President?"

All agreed, the best answer was, "Resign!"  No one present wanted that job.  We decided it is a 'Catch 22' job: If you want it, that clearly indicates you shouldn't have it, because only a crazy person would want it.

Apparently you missed the point I was making with my paen against Pres. Trump being qualified to be our Commander in Chief.  When it mattered, he put service to self against service to Country.

The Records of his local Draft Board duly records his history of 2S Student deferments for the four years he was in college, the change to 1A when he graduated, and the change to 1Y/4F, Unqualified to Serve shortly thereafter.  What is missing is any documentation to support the change to 1Y/4F.  Documentation the Selective Service required.

Add to that his statement that he couldn't remember the name of the doctor who wrote the "strongly worded letter" and the fact that neither the letter nor the doctor's name is in his records, and the story begins to, candidly, stink.  Speaking for myself, and probably at least half of those who served in that War, if I had a doctor who wrote a "strongly worded letter" excusing me from the Draft, you better believe I'd remember his name!

Addendum, approx. 5 minutes after posting the above:

Therefore, my conclusion is that somebody at his local Draft Board "pencil Whipped" in his 1Y/4F classification as a personal favor to him and/or his dad.  In short, he dodged the Draft, and honorable service to his Country.

This made the NFL¬†organization angry¬†and they decided to fire any body that took a kneel during the National Anthem. (a) Designation.‚Äî
    The composition consisting of the words and music known as the Star-Spangled Banner is the national anthem.
(b) Conduct During Playing.‚ÄîDuring a rendition of the national anthem‚Äî
    (1) when the flag is displayed‚Äî
      (A) individuals in uniform should give the military salute at the first note of the anthem and maintain that position until the last note;
     (B) members of the Armed Forces and veterans who are present but not in uniform may render the military salute in the manner provided for individuals in uniform; and
     (C) all other persons present should face the flag and stand at attention with their right hand over the heart, and men not in uniform, if applicable, should remove their headdress with their right hand and hold it at the left shoulder, the hand being over the heart; and
   (2) when the flag is not displayed, all present should face toward the music and act in the same manner they would if the flag were displayed.

SUKABUMI, Indonesia --Workers making Converse sneakers in
Indonesia say supervisors throw shoes at them, slap them in the face and call
them dogs and pigs. Nike, the brand's owner, admits that such abuse has occurred among
the contractors that make its hip high-tops but says there was little it could
do to stop it.That does not appear to explain abuses
that workers allege at the Pou Chen Group factory in Sukabumi, some 60 miles
from Jakarta. It didn't start making Converse products until four years after
Nike bought Converse. One worker there said she was kicked by a supervisor last
year after making a mistake while cutting rubber for soles. 



"We're powerless," said the woman, who like several others
interviewed spoke on condition of anonymity out of fear of reprisals. "Our
only choice is to stay and suffer, or speak out and be fired." 

The 10,000 mostly female workers at the Taiwanese-operated Pou Chen plant make
around 50 cents an hour. That's enough, for food and bunkhouse-type lodging,
but little else. Some workers interviewed by the AP in March and April
described being hit or scratched in the arm -- one man until he bled. Others
said they were fired after filing complaints. 

"They throw shoes and other things at us" said a 23-year-old woman in
the embroidery division. "They growl and slap us when they get angry. 

"It's part of our daily bread." 

Mira Agustina, 30, said she was fired in 2009 for taking sick leave, even
though she produced a doctor's note. 

"It was a horrible job," she said. "Our bosses pointed their
feet at us, calling us names like dog, pig or monkey." All are major insults
to Muslims. Indonesia is the world's most populous Muslim nation. 

At the PT Amara Footwear factory located just outside Jakarta, where another
Taiwanese contractor makes Converse shoes, a supervisor ordered six female
workers to stand in the blazing sun after they failed to meet their target of
completing 60 dozen pairs of shoes on time. 

"They were crying and allowed to continue their job only after two hours
under the sun," said Ujang Suhendi, 47, a worker at a warehouse in the
factory. The women's supervisor received a warning letter for the May incident
after complaints from unionized workers. 

The company's own inquiries also found workers at the two factories were
subjected to "serious and egregious" physical and verbal abuse,
including the punishment of forcing workers to stand in the sun, said Hannah
Jones, a Nike executive who oversees the company's efforts to improve working
conditions.

Although I agree with Kaepernick's message, I completely disagree with the method of delivering that message. Furthermore, I don't think he truly thought it through... instead of raising awareness about social injustice, his message became muddled and skewed, and  became a debate over patriotism and honoring our nation's flag and service members. And what has his protest accomplished, exactly? More people are arguing over the right to protest and showing respect for our flag as opposed to discussing the issues surrounding social injustice. Not to mention the fact that nothing has changed. Have any of the SJW's stepped up and taken any real action? If so, I haven't heard anything about it. But, I'm still hearing plenty about the debate over standing/kneeling for our nation's flag and anthem. 

I'm not entirely convinced Kaepernick's intentions are truly genuine and selfless either. I think he did this to cause controversy and make headlines for publicity. After all, they say there's no such thing as bad publicity. And now it's paid off in a nice lucrative deal with Nike. I'm wondering if he'll use any of the money he's making from this deal to help fight the social injustice he's supposedly so passionate about ü§î Do you think Nike truly cares? They saw an opportunity to create headlines and cash in on it. Like I said... no such thing as bad publicity. To those of you applauding Nike, this was strictly a strategic business decision on their part... nothing more and nothing less.

Not only are we conservatives going to dispose of our Nike apparel, but we will also stop buying Nike products. Nike ‚Äúnot worried about the backlash from a small segment of the American population‚Äù? If their revenue drops, then they‚Äôre going to regret not worrying about the actual large population of patriotic Americans. @Brad Christy 
I knew the answer and figured that would be the nature of your response. 

I've seen a lot of things I'd rather not have seen. And heard some too. So It's understandable when you have a choice what you take in.

I've found truth in some very difficult places. And the naked truth ain't always easy to look at. Its written "For in much¬†wisdom¬†is¬†much¬†grief:¬†and he that increases knowledge¬†increases¬†sorrow." Eccl. 1:18. Of course that doesn't refer to superficial knowledge/information and wisdom of our own making and preference. Its Knowledge and wisdom of the reality and truth about the world.
 We're pretty good at sectioning ourselves off into our own echo chambers,  mass/social media communities of choice.
So, yes. I get it. 
When I saw it, I thought a lot of people aren't going to like this, Colin In Black and White. I would have done some things a lot differently, especially that Combine, Cotton field, auction transition juxtaposition. 
Starting out  with that, and seeing him doesnt make it easy to watch.  But I looked at like "It's His story to tell, not mine.' 
I wish you could see it, but it's definitely not for you. 
Had it just been about his growing up and coming of age in High school  it would have been a rousing success, a great story. Noone would have had a problem with it. The young man who played him definitely has a bright future in acting, if they don't blackball him for playing a young Colin Kaepernick (Joke-smile). But the story is interspersed with vignettes on the history and nature of disconnected relations between so-called "Blacks" and "Whites." in America. 

Bottom line for me, Colin just isn't good at "being Black." But anyone who watches his growing up as portrayed in the series  will see and understand why.  And why even now he doesn't come off as genuine, and authentic in his "Blackness." 
Truth is,  Black isn't something you can be.  It's not a color, (like white isn't a color). Black is a Condition. 
Overcoming that, is what it will take the "Blacks" you were referring to realize they are not victims.

Peace my friend.

I‚Äôve gone through that ‚Äúdraft process‚Äù every time I‚Äôve applied for a job.

@Big Sweet C I‚Äôm not trying to be an ass here, because I understand that most people don‚Äôt know the ins and outs of these things. But a lot of them can afford to do that. Especially now with the NIL rules in college and the ability to sell signed memorabilia due to the fact that each NFL-potential-draftee is likely a star at his own school. But they have tons of options, including taking out insurance on their careers, or even taking out a loan from their agent if they‚Äôd like to sit a year because they got drafted by a team that they don‚Äôt think would be best for them. The issue of being forced to play for a team that drafts them impacts mostly the guys at the top because they are so sought after, but the advance from an agent I just mentioned is in play there because agents understand that these guys are going to sign a decent sized rookie contract. As for the other guys drafted later ‚Äî they could still go for that option ‚Äî but they are even more drafted by scheme and can also talk to teams a bit more about fit for themselves if they really wanted to. Players do this all the time, even at the top. If you are a nose tackle or true MLB, you hear all the time about the desire to go to the best fit. The NT would probably want to go to a team that plays a 3-4 and the MLB a 4-3. These things don‚Äôt come out by accident, they are trying to get to the best place possible for their success. And again ‚Äî the guy who is in college and wants to shoot for the NFL, but is project to go 5-7 or undrafted who doesn‚Äôt have a back-up plan gets no pity from me. All of us normal people have to have a plan-B and even plan-C.
@ÂêçÁÑ°„Åó „ÄÇ„ÄÇ I‚Äôm talking about a draft. No players don‚Äôt have a choice. They for all intents and purposes have to sign with the team that drafts them.

@Jimmy W. ok-name one person and especially a young athlete who can throw away a year of earning potential. And then they‚Äôd simply be forced to play for the next team that drafts them. A true free market would be for players to become free agents as soon as their eligible to play in the pros.

@Big Sweet C  and also what you said about a player being forced to sign with the team that drafts them isn‚Äôt true. Players are allowed to hold out for an entire year and re-enter the draft the next year. They aren‚Äôt obligated to do anything until they sign a contract willingly.

@Big Sweet C  that‚Äôs like saying software engineers, which are the smartest among us are forced to work for Google. They could go work for Geico or a start-up, just like these players could go play for the arena league or the CFL, but the engineers won‚Äôt because they want to get paid the most by the biggest company. These players are employees, and the NFL is a giant company that was a giant monetary risk for many for nearly 60-years. They are making money now with an established brand/sport due to the monetary risks others took. Yes these men take major health risks to play, but it‚Äôs their decision. Many of us in the real world need back-up career plans in case things don‚Äôt work out. I‚Äôm in the middle of a career change as we speak. So if the NFL doesn‚Äôt work out for them and they don‚Äôt have a back-up plan, then it is what it is. People in the real world also don‚Äôt always have the chance to leave or go for another job whenever they want. We sign contracts and have non-competes in the business world. As for salary caps, I agree, I think those are bogus in all sports. But again, it‚Äôs a business that makes the rules.

It‚Äôs an entire separate convo to discuss education in the black community and policies that have kept these places down, but 1/16,000 athletes turn pro in their sport. I‚Äôm not feeling sorry because someone made a choice to focus on football and now they are vetted/tested by a team to make sure they are an adequate fit for their ‚Äúcompany‚Äù. I didn‚Äôt have my arm or vert tested for where I work now, but I bet these guys didn‚Äôt get asked if they are proficient in Excel. I also can‚Äôt respond ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just here so I don‚Äôt get fined‚Äù to anyone I come across during the day either.

Not really. The draft is actually the exact opposite of free market capitalism. I‚Äôm not disputing they aren‚Äôt paid well but players would actually make considerably more without artificial deflation in place because of salary caps and rookie scales and ‚Äúmax salaries‚Äù. You also have the right to apply to any job at any time. Even assuming for a minute that Kaepernick believes this stuff, the NFL (and all sports leagues) are not a good example of market capitalism.
